summary: A detailed presentation illustrating the unexpected depth and significance of Rock, Paper, Scissors through the story of the World Rock Paper Scissors Society.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a person standing on a stage, delivering a presentation. The stage is dimly lit, with a spotlight focused on the speaker, who is positioned behind a podium. The background features a large screen displaying the text "ROCK" with a graphic of a rock and the words "PECHAKUCHA NIGHT CALGARY" beneath it, indicating the event's theme and location. The audience is visible in the foreground, attentively watching the presentation. The scene transitions to a close-up of the screen, which now shows the name "Douglas Walker" and the title "Associate Professor, World Art Paper Conservation Society," providing information about the speaker's identity and affiliation. The video continues with the speaker actively engaging with the audience, gesturing with their hands while speaking. The large screen remains visible in the background, displaying the same text about Douglas Walker. The atmosphere is formal and focused, with the audience's attention directed towards the speaker. The video concludes with the speaker still on stage, continuing their presentation, maintaining the same setting and atmosphere throughout.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a female voice introducing Douglas Walker, mentioning his background in advertising, his published work, and his reputation as an authority on a subject that "doesn't matter at all," in a slightly humorous tone. As she finishes the introduction, applause erupts. Following the applause, a male voice says "Hello" in a normal speaking tone, and a dog barks.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man standing at a podium on a stage, delivering a presentation to an audience. The large screen behind him displays various images and text. Initially, the screen shows the name "Douglas Walker" and the title "World Bank Paper Generator Society." The man, dressed in a dark suit and tie, gestures with his hands as he speaks. The screen then transitions to a black and white image of a clenched fist, symbolizing strength or solidarity. Following this, the screen displays a serene winter landscape with snow-covered trees and a frozen lake, accompanied by a smaller inset image of the same scene. The presentation continues with the man speaking, and the screen changes to a logo featuring a shield with a green top, a white middle, and a blue bottom, along with the text "World Bank Paper Generator Society" and the tagline "Serving the needs of decision-makers since 1918." The audience remains engaged throughout the presentation, with the stage and podium consistently visible in the foreground.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a man giving a presentation, beginning with a bit of humor to introduce his topic of "rock," which he equates to a "closed fist powering down on a poorly chosen pair of scissors." He becomes more serious as he shares how rock paper scissors consumed a third of his attention for a decade. He shares a memory of a particularly intense rock paper scissors match with his brother at his parents' cottage, which eventually led to the creation of "The World Rock Paper Scissors Society."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man standing at a podium, delivering a presentation to an audience. The background screen displays various slides, starting with the logo and tagline of the World Rock Paper Scissors Society, "Serving the needs of decision-makers since 1918." The presentation then transitions to a slide showing a list of items, followed by a slide with two logos, "The Avalanche" and "Scissor Sandwich," each accompanied by a tagline. The next slide illustrates the concepts of "Rock," "Paper," and "Scissors," with corresponding images and attributes such as "Power," "Stealth," and "Ingenuity." The final slide shows a poster with the text "Scissor Cut Paper" and "World Rock Paper Scissors Society," along with a smaller inset image of a book cover titled "Scissor Out Paper." Throughout the presentation, the man gestures and speaks, engaging with the audience. The setting appears to be a conference or seminar, with a darkened room and focused lighting on the speaker and screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker beginning a presentation, remarking with a humorous tone about a back-story he and his company developed. He then explains that he was left with the notion that there seemed to be more to the game than he initially thought and started a website, followed by a comment about what websites used to look like. The speaker defines gambits, relating them to rock, paper, scissors, and continues to describe how the game doesn’t leave much of a trace in anthropological records so they created the culture and history of rock, paper, scissors without the constraints of facts. He continues by noting that they took a lot of inspiration from communist and cultural revolution imagery, because people always had their fists out with the labor movement, speaking in a clear, informative tone throughout, frequently interrupted by laughter from an audience.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man standing at a podium, speaking to an audience. Behind him, a large screen displays various images and text related to the World Rock Paper Scissors Society. The first image on the screen shows a hand holding scissors cutting through paper, with the text "Scissors Cut Paper" and "World Rock Paper Scissors Society" below it. The next image is a membership card for the society, with the text "World Rock Paper Scissors Society Official Membership Card" prominently displayed. The screen then shows a photo of a man in a suit holding a trophy, with the text "World Rock Paper Scissors Society" and "Official Membership Card" visible. The final image on the screen is a collage of various media outlets, including CNN, Rolling Stone, and Forbes, with the text "World Rock Paper Scissors Society" and "Official Membership Card" again visible. The man at the podium continues to speak throughout the video, and the audience appears engaged. The setting is a dimly lit room with a large screen as the focal point, creating an atmosphere of a presentation or lecture.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing an event, mentioning it "meant a lot to us" and worked "really, really well" for the movement. He notes selling memberships and merchandise, leading to the creation of the "Goddamn World Championships of Rock Paper Scissors." The speaker describes the intensity of the game and the event's popularity, referencing CBS, ABC, and BBC fighting for pictures of "Master Rochambeau," the "Michael Jordan of the sport." Light music then plays in the background.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man standing at a podium, delivering a presentation in a dimly lit room. Behind him, a large screen displays various images and text. Initially, the screen shows a collage of media logos, including CNN, Rolling Stone, and Forbes, alongside a group of people dressed in cowboy hats and suits. The scene transitions to a book cover titled "Rock, Paper, Scissors," with an inset image of the book. The screen then displays a building with green windows and a purple mailbox, followed by a collage of images featuring a woman holding a trophy, surrounded by flags of Norway, the United Kingdom, and Australia. The presentation continues with a comparison between FOX Sports and ESPN logos, with the inset image showing the same logos. Throughout the video, the man at the podium gestures and speaks, engaging the audience with the visual content on the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip consists of a stand-up comedy performance, featuring a male speaker recounting humorous anecdotes about Rock Paper Scissors. He describes how they exaggerated someone's importance to the media, the publication of an official strategy guide, and a documentary that won an award at Slamdance. The speaker jokingly shares that other countries began sending their champions and mentions how the ego of a Rock Paper Scissors champion is unbelievable. He said one of the hardest decisions he ever had to make was deciding whether Fox or ESPN should get the television rights. He also adds that Rock Paper Scissors is not as good of a televised sport as you might think it is. He speaks in an energetic and humorous tone, pausing for audience laughter. The general ambient noise in the background suggests a live audience.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man standing at a podium, delivering a presentation in a dimly lit room. Behind him, a large screen displays various images and text. Initially, the screen shows a Guinness World Records 2008 cover alongside a photo of a rock-paper-scissors contest, with the text "LARGEST ROCK, PAPER, SCISSORS CONTEST" visible. The man, dressed in a dark suit and tie, gestures with his hands as he speaks, engaging with the audience. The atmosphere is formal, with the audience seated in darkness, focusing on the speaker and the screen. The screen then transitions to display the text "Sotheby's vs. Christie's," indicating a comparison or competition between the two auction houses. The man continues his presentation, maintaining a professional demeanor throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker who starts by referring to a past event he’s glad did not happen again. He then transitions to discussing a 2008 Guinness World Record achievement—winning the largest rock paper scissors competition—noting the contrast between his inner child’s excitement and his adult self’s perception that "Guinness has really jumped the shark." The speaker's tone is generally casual, with moments of humor.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man standing at a podium, delivering a presentation in a dimly lit room with an audience in the background. The large screen behind him displays the text "Sotheby's vs. Christie's," indicating a comparison or competition between the two renowned auction houses. The man, dressed in a dark suit, gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing his points. The screen then transitions to an image of two black dice, suggesting a metaphorical or illustrative element related to the presentation's topic. The overall atmosphere is formal and focused, with the audience's attention directed towards the speaker and the visual aids on the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker recounting an interesting story. He begins by noting that a Japanese gentleman sold an art collection worth approximately $20 million featuring famous artists. Unable to decide which auction house to use, he settled it with "Rock, Paper, Scissors". The speaker emphasizes that this was "the largest, most expensive Rock, Paper, Scissors match in history of $12 million".

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man stands on a stage, delivering a presentation to an audience. He is dressed in a dark suit and is positioned behind a podium with a microphone. The stage is dimly lit, focusing the audience's attention on the speaker and the large screen behind him. The screen initially displays an image of two black dice with white dots, accompanied by a smaller inset image in the top right corner showing a coin and dice. The man gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing his points. The screen then transitions to a new image featuring various hand gestures with percentages next to them, such as a fist labeled "~37%" and a peace sign labeled "~29%". The inset image in the top right corner changes to show different hand gestures with their respective percentages. The man continues to speak and gesture, engaging with the audience and the content displayed on the screen. The overall atmosphere is one of a formal presentation or lecture, with the speaker actively communicating information to the audience.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features one male speaker discussing a game that might seem like chance, but actually involves "two people making an active decision". He emphasizes that people are subject to it and that data from thousands of matches supports his point. He mentions that rock is the most frequent choice and that players tend to shy away from scissors.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man standing at a podium, delivering a speech in a dimly lit room. Behind him, a large screen displays a poster with the text "WORLD RPS SOCIETY" and "LEAD ON WITH YOUR ROCKS, PAPER AND SCISSORS," accompanied by an illustration of three people in dynamic poses. The man, dressed in a dark suit, gestures with his hands as he speaks, occasionally looking at the audience. The scene transitions to a new screen displaying the word "ROCK" in bold letters, with a graphic of a rock and the text "PECHAMUCHA NIGHT CALGARY 17" below it. The background of this screen features a celestial theme with planets and stars. The man continues his speech, now with the new screen behind him, and the audience is visible in the foreground, attentively watching the presentation. The atmosphere is formal and focused, with the speaker engaging with the audience through his gestures and the visual aids on the screen.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker on stage, who initially states he's leaving the audience with "one final thought". He introduces a "top 7 rock paper scissors strategist" named C. Barns, sharing Barns's quote: "Paper is the answer, should rock be the question?" This is said with emphasis, and the speaker concludes by thanking the audience. Immediately following, there is loud applause, conveying appreciation for the speech.
